chapter.title: Creating a New Project
chapter.para: So - you are a freshly registered CodeX user and you want to make your developer or project leader life easier. In other words you want to:

listitem.para: Avoid the pain and cost of creating your own project infrastructure (with servers and backup)
Avoid paying a premium price for commercial version control, defect tracking and task management tools

Quickly setup a project environment that you can share with your colleagues, your partners, your contractors or your customers where ever they are while keeping your information safe and under control.
Make your organization globally more productive and efficient by possibly letting others re-use your software and build on it.

chapter.para: If any of these points is appealing to you then you should definitely host your software project on CodeX. Let's see how you can do that.

section.title: Project Registration
section.para: Before you create a new project you must be a registered user (see ). You then login and select the item "Register New Project" in the upper part of the CodeX Main Menu.
The project registration is a 7-step process:

listitem.para: Some information about CodeX Services. Just read it.

Here we want you to know about the kind of services that we, the CodeX Team, are going to provide you with. This page also tells you about a few things we ask you to do, and not to do, in order to be good citizens and to be compliant with the company policies. To proceed to the next step select [I AGREE] at the end of the document. If you select [I DISAGREE] please contact us and tell us why. May be we can help you solve the problem.

This is where the rubber hits the road! Tell us about your project. Give an accurate description. This is really important if you want to maximize the chance of re-use by others. Also list any information related to Intellectual Property like Invention Proposal or Patents related to the software whether pending or already filed. Give the list of software needed (whether internal or 3rd party) to make your own software run properly. And the last field is entirely for you. Write down all the things that you consider as crucial for your project or for the community of users.

Give the project short name and the project full name. Carefully read the restrictions that apply to both names before you type anything. The full name can be changed at any time in the life of the project. The short name cannot
Actually it can but you have to ask the CodeX Team to do it for you.. So think about it twice before you make a decision!

Most of the time the only valid choice here is the default one: "&SYS_ORG_NAME; Code eXchange Policy". As explained earlier in this document the CodeX Team assisted by &SYS_ORG_NAME; lawyers have carefully crafted the CodeX Policy and it is very unlikely that you need to create your own. If you do you'll have to talk to us and to the &SYS_ORG_NAME; Legal Department to validate it. A number of truly Open Source licenses are also mentioned in the list. Finally you can also choose you own licensing conditions.
Just to remind you that once your project is approved you'll have to categorize it according to the seven criteria listed in .

Last chance to review the submitted information before you send it to the CodeX Team for validation. Don't worry: the project members can later update all pieces of information shown on this page. If it's all ok with you then click on [I AGREE]. If you click on [I DISAGREE] the pre-registered project will be deleted from the CodeX database and all the information you have typed so far are lost.

section.para: After you validate the project registration, the CodeX Team reviews the information you submitted and decides to approve it or not. This process can take up to 24 hours but in most cases it's less than a couple of hours. So far all projects have been accepted so there is little to fear ... Shortly after the CodeX Team approval you'll receive an e-mail summarizing the characteristics of your project including a pointer to your new "Project Summary" page. Bookmark it in a safe place!

section.title: Post-Registration Configuration
section.para: The first thing to do after you receive the confirmation for your project registration is to visit the "Project Summary" page (URL included in the e-mail) and finish the configuration of your project. The 2 following actions are the most frequent ones that have to be taken after a project is registered:

para.emphasis: Categorize your project in the Software Map

listitem.para: Your project categorization appears on your "Project Summary" page. To categorize your project select the "categorize it now" link and fill out the category form fields.

Once a project is created, the creator is assigned the role of project administrator on this project. It is her responsability to define who are the project members and what their permissions are. This can be done by accessing the "Project Admin" page, typing the names of all the registered users promote as team members and then define their permissions.

tip.title: Tip: Cannot find an appropriate Topic? Contact us
tip.para: Rather than putting in place a heavy hierarchy of project topics and sub-topics, the CodeX Team has decided to start small and create only a handful of top-level topics in the hierarchy. As time goes and as more and more projects register on CodeX we'll refine the hierarchy. If you cannot find the appropriate topic for your project, please contact us through the "Contact Us" link in the CodeX Main Menu or submit a request in the appropriate Discussion Forum.
